data.description: Nakdong Estuary Eco-Center, located where the river meets the ocean, is a habitat for migratory birds. The center focuses on research, maintenance, and education about the ecology of the wetlands. The center not only has various programs, but also a wild animal treatment center, experience center, observatory and more.
data.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Oryukdo Lighthouse (ì˜¤ë¥™ë„ ë“±ëŒ€)
dataList.description: Oryukdo is a rocky island located in the oceanside of the Yongho-dong neighborhood. Depending on the tides, Oryukdo (â€œOâ€ meaning â€œ5â€, â€œYukâ€ meaning â€œ6â€) sometimes looks as if it is made of five or six islets. Several decades after the Busanhang Port opened (1876), a lighthouse was built (November 1937) in Batseom Island of Oryukdo to guide ships traveling to and from the island. Initially only 6.2 meters high, the lighthouse underwent renovations (completed in December 1998) and now stands tall at 27.5 meters. The lighthouse is home to an exhibition room showing photos of major lighthouses in Korea and boasts a stunning view of Busanhang Port as well as an unforgettable nightscape.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Oryukdo Island [National Geopark] (ì˜¤ë¥™ë„ (ë¶€ì‚° êµ­ê°€ì§€ì§ˆê³µì›))
dataList.description: Oryukdo Island refers to a group of rocky islands off the southern coast of Busan. Depending on the day and the tide, it may appear to be five islands or six islands, hence the name ('o' meaning five and 'yuk' meaning six in Korean). The islands are full of cliffs, caves and free-roaming animals and plants. The islands were intact to the mainland approximately 120,000 years ago, but due to continuous wave erosion, island were separated.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Millak Waterfront Park (ë¯¼ë½ìˆ˜ë³€ê³µì›)
dataList.description:
Suyeong-gu is well known for its long history and traditions, and has beautiful scenery. Geumnyeonsan Mountain has a lush forest and Gwangalli Beach is located in the front. During the Joseon dynasty, this location was a strategically important region.
The Millak Waterfront Park was built between August 1992 and May 1997. The park is 543 meters long and 60 meters wide. Located between Haeundae Beach and Gwangalli Beach, it is the first park in Korea to combine the oceanfront with public rest and leisure facilities. The park (about 33,000 ã¡) can accommodate up to 40,000 people and boasts convenience facilities such as gardens, shaded rest areas, and benches. The 3,040 ã¡ platform from which visitors can overlook the beach also serves as a place where people can dip their feet in the ocean when the tide is high.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.description: When the lights lit up after sundown, the nightscape of the Marine City can compete with world famous nightscape locations such as Hong Kong and Shanghai. With various restaurants, cafes and bars along the street, it is a popular destination for people of all ages.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Ilgwang Beach (ì¼ê´‘í•´ìˆ˜ìš•ì¥)
dataList.description: Ilgwang Beach is a popular beach for families with a white sandy beach and Gangsongjeong Pine Tree Forest. With shallow waters and a clear view of the ocean, there is also Samseongdae Pavilion built during the late Joseon dynasty. There are numerous accommodation, dining and convenience facilities near the beach as well as a place to fish. Moreover, Ilgwang Beach hosts a festival annually in late July or early August.
dataList.author: korea-tour

dataList.title: Hwangnyeongsan Mountain (í™©ë ¹ì‚°)
dataList.description: Hwangnyeongsan Mountain offers a lush green forest easily accesible from downtown Busan. The mountain is popular for hiking, as well as taking in the nightscape. The mountain stretches across Busanjin-gu, Nam-gu, and Suyeong-gu districts, and with an altitude of 427 meters, it is the second tallest mountain in the Geumnyeon Mountain Range. Despite this distinction, the summit can be reached after a two to three-hour hike. At the foot of the mountain, one can find a citizen's recreation area and a youth training center. Choosing which mountain trail to take depends on the transportation options available.
